User Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (X11; Linux i686; rv:7.0.1) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/7.0.1
Build ID: 20110930134223

Steps to reproduce:

On Fedora 16 (linux), sawfish wm, XFCE4 desktop, click-to-focus

1. Open 2 separate Firefox (FF) windows
2. Put them side-by-side (or top-to-bottom) so they don't overlap and are both fully visible on the screen
3. Navigate to long page to provide scrollable scrollbars in each window
4. Focus window 1 (#1)
5. Click and hold down (drag) the scrollbar thumb in window 2 (#2)
6. Attempt to scroll by moving the mouse while dragging


Actual results:

Nothing: no scroll happens, no drag event appears to have happened.


Expected results:

Thumb should move, window should scroll.

This same test works fine if using any other app with a scrollbar, like a gnome-terminal, it appears specific to FF (not tested on other Mozilla apps).  Thus I am doubtful this is a wm issue.

Stranger still, this test works fine if #1 is FF and #2 is any other app (and vice versa)!  This strange behaviour only occurs between 2 FF windows.

Single-click events do work ok, even between 2 FF windows and even on the scrollbar.  It is only drag (probably mouse-down) events that are broken.

This bug applies to all dragging events, and can be demonstrated by attempting a left-drag across page content to highlight text instead of trying to use the scrollbar.

This worked perfectly fine in Fedora 14 with Firefox 3.6.

comments.raw_text:
Also, the same test while clicking and holding down the left mouse button on the non-thumb area of the scrollbar (to cause multiple page-up or down scrolling) works.  In that case it is registering the mouse-down and hold events and properly registers the mouse-up.

So it would appear it is entirely specific to the move-while-mouse-button-held-down case, with an emphasis on *move*.
